Bob Koss [mailto:koss@...] wrote:
> On 6/11/02 7:28 AM, "Michael Silverstein" <msilverstein@...>
> wrote:
>
> > Bob Koss [mailto:koss@...] wrote:
> >> But if we use Mediator to decouple the gui controls, we may as
> >> well delegate
> >> everything to the Mediator and leave the gui stupid. The
> Mediator can be
> >> unit tested just like any other class, and doesn't need the
> gui since all
> >> communication is done through interfaces.
> >
> > That notwithstanding, you still need to test the connection between the
> > mediator and your GUI. There's still plenty of room for error there.
>
>
> I'm trying to understand your concern. I can test that the
> Mediator send the
> right message with the right parameters at the right time. The code in the
> gui (let's say a Dialog box just to be concrete) that responds to this
> message is one or two lines of code which IMO, can't break.

The GUI is itself a framework composed of components (widgets) that each
encapsulate state. For example:
- contents, labels
- enabled/disabled
- shown/hidden
- color, font
- etc.

In order to change the state of those components there must be a
conversation from the model, or mediator in your example, to those widgets.
This conversation is typically implemented in > 0 lines of nontrivial code.
This code is prone to breakage.

On top of that you also have the conversation from the widgets to the
model/mediator. This also is prone to breakage, typically through
inappropriate use of listener callback arguments, or just simply forgetting
to set up a callback.

So you see, the statement that it "can't break" is just a bit overly
optimistic.
